Subject: Music
Text: By the end of Foundation, students describe the music they listen to at school, at home and in the community, identifying what they enjoy and why.

Subject: Music
Text: Students sing with pitch awareness and respond to the beat and simple rhythm patterns.

Subject: Music
Text: They explore contrasting sounds and improvise with them, using imagination and skills to create music.

Subject: Music
Text: They sing and play instruments to communicate their experiences and ideas.

Subject: Music
Text: By the end of Level 2, students identify where they experience music.

Subject: Music
Text: They describe where, why and how people across cultures, communities and other contexts experience music.

Subject: Music
Text: Students demonstrate listening skills when hearing and when making music.

Subject: Music
Text: They use the elements of music to improvise and/or compose music.

Subject: Music
Text: They share their music-making with audiences in informal settings.

Subject: Music
Text: By the end of Level 4, students identify and describe how elements of music are used in music they compose and/or perform.

Subject: Music
Text: They recall where, when, why and how music is created and presented across cultures, times, places and other contexts, including the music of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples.

Subject: Music
Text: Students use listening skills when performing, composing and listening to music.

Subject: Music
Text: Students use music knowledge and skills to create music in a range of forms that communicates ideas, perspectives and meaning.

Subject: Music
Text: They perform their work in formal and informal settings.

Subject: Music
Text: By the end of Level 6, students demonstrate how elements of music contribute to music they compose, perform and experience.

Subject: Music
Text: They recall how music composed and/or performed across cultures, times, places and other contexts communicates ideas, perspectives and meaning.

Subject: Music
Text: They identify how music is used to continue and revitalise cultures, including in the works of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples.

Subject: Music
Text: Students demonstrate listening and aural skills when listening, composing and performing.

Subject: Music
Text: They select and use elements of music and compositional devices to compose music that communicates ideas, and when practising music for a performance, and documenting and/or recording the music they compose.

Subject: Music
Text: They perform music in formal and informal settings, identifying different audiences.

Subject: Music
Text: By the end of Level 8, students analyse how the elements of music and compositional devices are manipulated in music they compose, perform and experience.

Subject: Music
Text: They describe ways music from across cultures, times, places and other contexts communicates ideas, perspectives and meaning, including in the works of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples.

Subject: Music
Text: They identify and describe how and why respectful approaches are used in composing, performing and responding to music.

Subject: Music
Text: Students exploit elements of music and compositional devices and demonstrate listening and aural skills to compose music that communicates ideas, perspectives and meaning.

Subject: Music
Text: They document/notate and/or record the music they compose.

Subject: Music
Text: They manipulate elements of music when performing their own and others’ music.

Subject: Music
Text: They demonstrate performance skills when performing music for audiences.

Subject: Music
Text: By the end of Level 10, students analyse and evaluate ways the elements of music and compositional devices are exploited to engage audiences in music they compose, perform and experience.

Subject: Music
Text: They investigate ways music from across cultures, times, places and other contexts communicates ideas, perspectives and meaning, including the practices of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander musicians.

Subject: Music
Text: They evaluate how music is used to celebrate and challenge perspectives of Australian identity, including those of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples.

Subject: Music
Text: Students demonstrate listening skills relevant to the styles in which they are working when composing, arranging and performing.

Subject: Music
Text: They document/notate and/or record their music.

Subject: Music
Text: They manipulate elements of music appropriate to the style when performing their own or others’ music.

Subject: Music
Text: They use music elements and compositional devices to compose music that communicates ideas, perspectives and meaning.

Subject: Music
Text: They demonstrate performance skills when performing music for audiences.
